section.title: Power Functions
section.p: In this activity, we will explore power functions.
A power function is a function of the form f(x) = x^a where a is a constant real number.
Our goal is to learn to predict what the graph of a power function will look like, depending on the exponent a.

paragraphs.title: Positive Integer Exponents
paragraphs.p: We will begin by examining power functions where the exponent n is a positive integer (1, 2, 3, \cdots ). In order to do this, we should briefly remind ourselves about the difference between even and odd exponents.

paragraphs.title: Negative Integer Exponents
paragraphs.p: Next, we will expand our set of power functions to include negative integer exponents. First, however, we should review the meaning of a negative exponent.

statement.p: A positive integer exponent refers to repeated multiplication: x^5 = x\cdot x\cdot x\cdot x\cdot x
It is often helpful to think of this as a product beginning with the number 1, so that we really have: x^5 = 1\cdot x\cdot x\cdot x\cdot x\cdot x

section.p: So, a variable raised to a negative exponent is the same as dividing by that variable raised to a positive exponent. Keep that in mind as you answer the next exercise.

statement.p: True or False: The function f(x) = x^{-2} always gives negative outputs, because it has a negative exponent.
Answer:
True or False: The function f(x) = x^{-2} never gives negative outputs, because it is the same as \frac{1}{x^2}, which is just 1 divided by a positive number.
Answer:
True or False: The function g(x) = x^{-3} always gives negative outputs, because it has a negative exponent.
Answer:
True or False: The function g(x) = x^{-3} will only give a negative output if the input is negative.

solution.p: First, we rewrite these functions so they have positive exponents: f(x) = x^{-2} = \frac{1}{x^2} and g(x) = x^{-3} = \frac{1}{x^3}
We know x^2 never gives negative outputs, so neither will x^{-2} = \frac{1}{x^2}.
We also know that x^3 will only give a negative output when x \lt 0, so the same is true about x^{-3} = \frac{1}{x^3}.

paragraphs.title: Fractional Exponents
paragraphs.p: We now explore the graphs of power functions which have fractional exponents of the form \frac{1}{n}.
Here, we only consider when the exponent is positive.

section.p: Before looking at graphs, we will briefly revisit the meaning of a fractional exponent.

statement.p: Recall the meaning of a fractional exponent. For example, the expression 9^{\frac{1}{2}} is the same as the square root of 9: 9^{\frac{1}{2}} = \sqrt{9} = 3

This can be justified by using properties of exponents. If we multiplied 9^{\frac{1}{2}} by itself, we would have: 9^{\frac{1}{2}}\cdot 9^{\frac{1}{2}} \amp= 9^{\frac{1}{2} + \frac{1}{2}} \amp= 9^1 \amp= 9
So, 9^{\frac{1}{2}} must be a square root of 9, because squaring it actually equals 9.

section.p: So we see that fractional exponents refer to n^{\rm{th}} roots: x^{\frac{1}{2}} is a square root, x^{\frac{1}{3}} is a cube root, etc. One should be careful when evaluating power functions of this type when the input x is negative. Some calculators/programs will evaluate an expression like (-8)^{\frac{1}{3}} differently, and actually not return a real number. In this course, we will treat x^{\frac{1}{3}} and \sqrt[3]{x} the same.
